text:
The question of the day, both here and in the United States, is whether Cleveland or Harrison, Mitchell or Fisher, had the plurality or the majority? We await the answer in dimm silence.

Since we raised the question as to the legality of the elections, many papers and officials have been heard from on the subject, but so far we have not heard any thing to convince us that there was no question of legality, but we notice that it appears to be the prevailing opinion that legislation at Ottawa will remove any doubts and legalise the North West Assembly.

The Regina Leader, speaking of the North West Assembly, says—“The Assembly is a very strong organization. The Legislators, even the Assemblymen, and merchants are far ahead of Manitobans.” True as to the relative abilities of the members of the two Legislatures, but as to the rest we cannot say. The Assembly is a rest too powerful. Manitoba settler and merchants are as good as any on the continent.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

MEDICINE HAT.

From the Pioneer, Nov. 9.
We had a little flurry of snow on Saturday morning.
Over one hundred people were entertained right royally at the Orangeman's Hall last night.
The city was lit up on Monday night by the light of a firework sent to the south.
Jos. Wm. Percy and wife, of Fort Saskatchewan, Alta., have been guests of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Smith this week.
Mr. Percy went east two weeks ago, and the marriage license was issued in Edmonton.
The bride was Miss Taylor, formerly of Medicine Hat. We extend our hearty congratulations to the young couple.

REGINA.

From the Journal, Nov. 8.
What has been raining during the past couple of days, some thousands of barrels have been marketed here. The establishment prices are low, but for some $15 it was paid yesterday.
Commissioners Robson and Matheson of the municipal police, embarked on a visit to the headquarters of Master Mason by entertaining the Masonic brethren to a banquet at the Windsor on Tuesday night.
Several of the municipal policemen, who are on duty in Saskatoon, attended dinner service at the Windsor on Sunday night, having been invited by members of the Salvation Army, were asked to assist in the service.
Mr. Fehrleibach, the inspector of the C.P.R. experimental farms, is in town collecting samples for the C.P.R. exhibition care.
He visited North Battleford on behalf of Master Mason this year. A committee of the Board of Trade is intending how to promote them in this vicinity, but he will not be able to visit the exhibits from each district will be kept separate and carefully handled.

LETHBRIDGE.

From the News, Nov. 8.
Chief Campbell returned home from taking prisoners to Regina on Saturday last.
The weather for this week looked being very fine indeed; so, very fine and the nights not very cold, ranchers are busy harvesting whatever marketable vegetables they may have on hand.
There is a ready market for them from the grocers and provision merchants.
The rivers in this vicinity rose to a considerable height on Friday, but the day laid and were impassable for freight teams which in consequence had to go back by the old Up Line to Fort Macleod.
The same was the case Saturday, but by the warm spell of the few days previous melting the snow in the mountains.
Mr. Gilmore, of Manitoba, arrived here this morning with a carload of two and three-year-old calves which he holds for sale. The cattle are in good condition, better than we have ever seen, being large, well graded and in good condition.

FORT MACLEOD.

From the Gazette, Nov. 8.
The post mill business was wound up on Saturday. Some $45 expenses were returned to be paid, and the balance remaining, less taxes, to those who had paid the fees.
Lumber & McArthur, solicitors for the Alberta & Athabasca Railway Co., are now engaged in the erection of its offices, giving attention to its erection, construction, equip and operate its line of railway from its northern terminus point at Macleod to the Canadian Pacific Railway, whereby to the international boundary; and also from its northern terminus point at Macleod to the Peace River, northwesterly to the Peace River, and to increase the coastal stock thereof, as per agreement.
On Thursday a party of prisoners named Wright, confined in the guard room on a charge of an assault, for selling liquor, were released on bail. The prisoners have not yet been captured. The prisoners' weight on the head, were sitting out in the yard when they were released from their bonds. As soon as Wright took his pipe out of his mouth, he made a bolt and escaped from the yard. The matter was investigated, and as a result, Sergeant O'Neill was released to the custody of Const. Watts.

Charles Steenman, in charge of the ox-hay team at Stood Off, met with what might have been a fatal accident while on his way to Macleod.
The four horses team he was driving ran away and pulled him down. His head struck against the front wheel, which hit him on the ground, and the horses fell and brought the team to rest when Charlie released himself.
For his injuries he was badly cut, though he received no serious or permanent injuries.

CALGARY.

From the Tribune, Nov. 7.
Last week a court martial with match set for to see something in the Palace hotel, but fortunately it was discovered before it was too late.
Half-breed are packing out on an average 300 pounds of meat per day from their camps close to the line to Aamodot. Most of it comes out by the Northern Pacific. The cow are valued at $100 per ton. Mr. Wright will probably about the same price for his herd's claims.
Friday night was 6 o'clock the firemen were called out to put out an alarm and in a few minutes the whole town was on the streets to find out where the fire was. In a short time the fire was extinguished, but the firemen could not get at the fire, and on further inquiry it was found to be caused by Mr. Wright's cow.
The firemen, ten in number, were paid $200 and was soon completely demolished. Mr. Wright's losses will be about $500 on his herd's claims.

THE LAST RITES.

It is with deep regret that we have to announce the death of Mr. George A. Miller, one of our most esteemed and re-
spected citizens. About four weeks ago he was taken ill with an infectious fever which finally developed into ty-
phoid. No fears were entertained of his recovery, but unfortunately when from a slight draft he took a re-
lapse and presently set in and although his physicians had been unable to save his sufferings, yet in Sabbath morning 
last at about six o’clock he passed over to join the great majority. Mr. Miller was one of the first settlers to this settlement, to which he came a number of years ago and took up a homestead a few miles from here. He owned considerable property in the east-
ern part of the town where he resided for past thirty-three years and still followed the avocation of a farmer. He took a deep interest in all matters per-
taining to the welfare of the town and his death was chairman of the Board of Trustees Prince Albert East End Public 
School. In religion he was devout and constant member and regular at 
tenant of the Presbyterian church. He was known as a kind and affectionate husband and father, a generous and obliging neighbor. He leaves be-
hind him a wife and six children, three of whom are now living. He died of typhoid fever. His body was placed in a very handsome casket, covered with a beautiful black silk shroud, and left in his office as tyler of a Masonic hall. The funeral took place on Sunday last and the deceased was buried with Masonic honors by the members of the fraternity to which he belonged as tyler of the hall. The remains of the Masonic fraternity assembled at the hall at 12:30 and were driven there to the residence of their late brother and tyler and there remained until noon at which a part of the beautiful and im-
pressive Masonic burial service was con-
ducted. The services were officiated 
by the late Mr. D. M. B. Rev. 
Rev. Canon Fleet. At three o’clock the body was placed in the hearse and proceeded to the grave. The P.A.S. 
band, also consisting of the members of the Masonic fraternity, in full regalia; 
then came the ladies following, followed by friends, members of the St. Andrew’s Society and friends in carriage. On arrival at the grave the coffin containing the body was placed over the grave, and the Rev. Dr. Jardine held the burial service of the Fredrickson family after which the Masonic fraternity closed their eyes and the body of their late brother lay in its last resting place. The funeral, in spite of the severe weather, was attended by a large number of friends and members of the largest—of not the largest—over 
seen in Prince Albert. We are glad that this is the first time ever that a Funeral 
or fellow citizen ever preceded on a similar occasion in this district, and it is need-
less to say he performed his duties ad 
and well.

DUCHE LAKES.

Mr. A. J. MacNeil, Labrador’s clerk 
here, was married Saturday afternoon to 
Miss M. McNair, of Charlottetown. We wish them every success and prosper-
ity. He will be back in about a month.

Mr. A. J. Vincent, clerk of the Land 
Department, has been transferred from Quinton Lake to Snake Plain agency, where he arrived yesterday.

Sergeant Morrison, of Batesville, is in this district arranging for the return of seed 
grain lost some time ago to settlers.

Baptism occurred, and was recorded in the matter of a family, who were distin-
guished between here and Carlton. This is needed 
very badly, as parents are compelled to send their children away for a dis-
tance of from five to eight miles.

The dinner on Saturday evening, Mr. Mitchell’s birthday, was most enjoyable, 
a success. Special mention must be made 
of Messrs. Ambrose Fisher, Louis Martin, S. M. McCaffrey, John McKenzie, J. Kelly, Mr. J. F. Smith, and others whose 
were highly entertaining, especially those 
by Mr. S. R. McNaughton and Mr. Fisher. We only hope Mr. Mitchell had five or 
six birthdays in a year.

An old Indian brought in this week 
one deer, one moose and two elk.

Mr. T. W. Smith will go on Wednes-
day for the north end fishing expedition. He will market them in your town.

Great quantities of freight have been 
pending at the port for Snake Plain 
and other points north.

Stuart & Co. have just got in their 
winter goods.

THE ROADS IN THIS PART ARE VERY BAD, 
BEING NEITHER WHEELING OR SLIDING.

There is an excellent race at Carlton on 
pony races. The animals were owned by 
Messrs. Smith and Bird, the latter winning by 
two lengths.

We understand the post will be again 
running on December 1st. Jack Mc-
Caffrey will be employed on the road working night and day putting it in re-
pair, and good work may be expected.

Sergeant Morrison, of the N.W. Mounted 
Police, is on the mail. He will be sta-
tioned at Prince Albert.
